# Introduction - the role of Norwegian small-scale grazing systems within global food security challenge

When facing the upcoming challenge regarding global food security [@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012], with a food demand expected to increase between 30% and 62% by 2050 [@vandijkMetaanalysisProjectedGlobal2021], the temptation to dive into a "crop-mania" has already received some warnings [@foleySolutionsCultivatedPlanet2011; @hunterAgriculture2050Recalibrating2017]. Not only the core of the problem revolves more around food availability, through for instance waste control and diet changes, than strict food production [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013; @kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012; @westLeveragePointsImproving2014], but there is only limited potential for both intensification and expansion of agricultural lands without conflicting with other land uses [**REF**], long-term preservation of natural capital [@foleyGlobalConsequencesLand2005] and/or biodiversity conservation [@beckmannConventionalLandUse2019; @flynnLossFunctionalDiversity2009; @newboldGlobalEffectsLand2015]. 
<!-- There has been ongoing debate about land sharing vs land sparing (+ sustainable intensification)... -->
<!-- sustainable intensification has been presented as a solution to be able to fulfill the food production objectives (should look at: Godfray and Garnett, 2014; Cassman and Grassini, 2020) + short description of what sustainable intensification is (optimisation production, crop-based, biotech...) - also @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017 and @pywellWildlifefriendlyFarmingIncreases2015 -->
In that regard, the livestock sector plays a key role as animal products account for the largest land use [@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012], and demand is projected to increase even in Western countries [@alexandratosWorldAgriculture20302012]. With farming intensification, grain feed has become increasingly important in the animal feed mix to the detriment of pasture-based systems [**REF**]. Besides massive land surface cost [@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012] and food waste [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013], this increasing disconnection between feed and livestock has externalised environmental impacts to countries growing crops and producing feeds [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013; @naylorLosingLinksLivestock2005]. Thus, relying on pasture-based husbandry in Western countries would not only benefit local biodiversity but would also lessen the crop production burden in the Southern hemisphere [@foleySolutionsCultivatedPlanet2011].

In Europe, land use changes during the past decades have already altered the agricultural landscape [@jongmanHomogenisationFragmentationEuropean2002], and keeping on the intensification track would sacrifice habitats of high conservation values [@bignalLowIntensityFarmingSystems1996a; @haladaWhichHabitatsEuropean2011] without providing such a substantial increase in productivity or profitability for the farmer [@garibaldiFarmingApproachesGreater2017; @jeanneretIncreaseFoodProduction2021]. The areas under permanent meadows and pastures have drastically declined for the past 60 years [FAO DATA, 2020], and the trend is expected to continue whichever food production scenario [@wirseniusHowMuchLand2010]. Yet, semi-natural grazing systems not only ensure food sovereignty of local communities, but they have also shaped the biological and cultural diversity of landscapes [@jongmanHomogenisationFragmentationEuropean2002; @vosTrendsEuropeanCultural1999] and drawn a strong sense of belonging from people.


- importance of choosing a "yield gap closing strategy" which is embedded within local communities' cultural values and adapted to local environment and historical land use in order to prevent landscape homogenisation [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013]

# Chapter 1 - Small-scale grazing systems in Western Norway

Though Norway has followed the same intensification track as other European countries, leading to strong decline of the number of holdings as well as increase of average holding size [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010; @forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014], it ha been buffered by strong topographic and climatic constraints coupled with important support from public authorities towards the maintenance of farming practices and lifestyle [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986]. However, the trend was not even across the country, with flat, productive lands being heavily intensified while mechanisation and field improvement were limited in the fjords and the mountains [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010; @fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999]. These more environmentally-constrained areas have on the other hand suffered from land abandonment caused by socio-economic decline and population ageing of rural areas [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014]. The co-occurrence of farming intensification and land abandonment at two extreme ends of Norwegian agro-ecosystems has led to landscape homogenisation and loss of biological and cultural values [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988].

The highly touristic fjord region of Western Norway, where is located the Nordhordland Biosphere Reserve, still showcases the typical diversity of practices, land uses and landscapes of Norwegian small-scale farming systems [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010; @kalandNordhordlandBiosphereReserve2018]. First signs of land management by humans in Western Norway draws back to early Neolithic, with vegetation burning, allowing the development of heathlands [@hjelleLongtermChangesRegional2018; @prosch-danielsenPalaeoecologicalInvestigationsReconstruction2000], and introduction of domestic grazers [@hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006; @mehlCulturalLandscapeDevelopment2015a]. It is during the Iron Age that infield-outfield systems, which have shaped the agricultural landscape up to present days, started to develop [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991; **needs Western Norway specific**]. Through grazing and heath-cutting, a flow of nutrients and energy is created from low-productive outfields, such as heathlands and shrublands, to more productive infields and arable lands. Thus outfields not only serve as winter forage for animals, but also provide manure and mulch to fertilise and protect the crops. The outfield-infield system had been at the heart of self-sustaining farms from traditional farmer-fisherman livelihood [@hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986; @jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988], and still stands as the promoter of the highest level of biological and cultural diversity in agro-ecosystems [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991].

In present days, the tight synergy between outfield and infield managements has faded, along with the transition of farm structures [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010; @hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986; @wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018]. Some practices have disappeared, such as heath scything [**REF**], but others are locally maintained, as for example prescribed burning in coastal heathlands which ensures conservation of rustic livestock breeds such as norskgammelsau ("Old Norwegian sheep") [**REF**]. Another declining trend, which is yet very important for maintaining biodiversity of high conservation value in mountain areas, is the use of summer farms [**REF**]. Like their coastal counterparts, subalpine heathlands [^1] are grazed all year round by rustic sheep breeds, but they also have been traditionally used for summer grazing of goats and local cheese production [**REF**]. [*sentence on trends summer farms*].

Reviewing traditional practices in Western Norway highlights the plurality of tasks held by former communities of farmer-fishermen, who combined the use of sea and land resources to feed the family and make a living [@jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988]. This *pluriactivity* has mostly been maintained up to nowadays, though it has evolved as the farm shifted from being the centre of subsistence strategy to hardly economically viable activity at the periphery of regular job at the closest urban area [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006; @hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986]. Thus, holdings and livestock flocks have mainly remained small, and farming has upgraded through the diversification of livestock and the incorporation of contemporary management tools and techniques for productivity improvements of infields.

### The fjord system

The fjords in Western Norway are characterized by undulating topography which grows sharper in the inner fjord area [STILL NEED TO DEFINE THESE AREAS AT SOME POINT?]. The following features can affect plant and beetle assemblages by filtering the *natural* species pool at wider scale:

- the **elevation**: our study focused on grasslands in the "lowlands", thus the elevation gradient was limited with all of our sites located below 200 m. Yet, even at low level elevation can have an effect on local climate. including temperatures and precipitations [@zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013].
-- the **annual precipitations**:
- the **average maximal temperature of the warmer month**:
- the **average minimal temperatue of the coldest month**:
- the **distance to sea**: fjords are first and foremost defined by the sea arms which enter deeply into the land. These geological formations greatly affect the local climate by constraining wind currents and clouds [REF].

- temperature and precipitation will affect seasonal phenological dynamic of the plants, and thus response to management [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018]

### The landscape matrix

Land use being greatly constrained by the fjord topography, the agricultural landscape is usually diverse with woodlands and semi-managed outfields mixing with the grazing fields. The different habitat types around the site will affect the species pools and flows [REF]:

- the **forest percent cover**: it is common for land owners in the fjord countryside to keep some forested areas for wood supply. The dominant assemblages should not be affected in case of limited forest surface cover, but a landscape mainly dominated by forest may affect the species pools of the fields.
- the **wetland percent cover**: the fjords in Western Norway are well-irrigated thanks to a high precipitation level [REF]. Same as for the forest cover, it is likely that the common plant species pool will not be affected, but hygrophilous beetles (e.g. Hydrophilidae, Ptilidae) could be found in surrounding areas.
- the **cultivated land percent cover**: small-scale farming involves a high variety of food production strategies to adapt to the productivity gradient, with a limited use of agricultural machinery [REF]. Cultivated land are usually represented by fodder crops and orchards, which could influence the dominant pool of forbs in the surrounding grazing fields.
- the **outfield percent cover**: traditional grazing management in Western Norway revolved around the combined use of low productive outfields (usually heathlands or shrublands) and high productive infields, with biomass taken from the former in summer (e.g. heath mowing or summer grazing), to enrich the latter [REF]. There can be a fine line between outfields and infields, especially closer to the coast. A high cover of outfield would induce an overall lower productivity of the area.
- the **infield percent cover**: infields correspond to more conventional grazing areas, such as meadows and pastures. In an infield-dominant landscape, we would expect the dominant plant and beetle pools to be relatively stable.

### The grazing management

To accommodate the constraining topography and the limited resources, grazing like farming practices are very diverse. Grazing is a well-studied habitat pressure which can trigger contrasting responses depending on its intensity and the local context [REF]:

- the **type of livestock**: traditional grazing management in Western Norway used to rely on sheep breeding, but the livestock has been diversified with cow and goat flocks. Each type of livestock has distinct grazing patterns and diet preferences which can affect the plant community [REF]. The type of excretions, which differs a lot between ruminants and other herbivores, is also likely to influence the dung-beetle assemblage.
- the **stocking density**: productivity being a major limiting factor in fjord areas, grazing systems in Western Norway can be qualified as extensive, even on the most productive infields. However, there will still be a gradient of intensity according to the type of grazer, the number of animals and the grazing area.
- the **farm infield surface**: rotational grazing is an important component of small-scale farming. The farmer divides the area into smaller fields where the livestock stays on shorter periods and rotates regularly during the year. Higher rotational capacity in extensive management system entails a lower grazing intensity.
- the **size of the field**: due to this rotational grazing system on a limiting topography, the size of each individual field can vary a lot between farms and within the same farm. A smaller field will be more sensitive to disturbances and to changes in species flows, and will be more subjected to edge effect [REF].

### The fine-scale environment

The last filters which apply to the plant and beetle assemblages would be the ones to define their immediate ecological niches, from both above- and below-ground [REF]:

- the **slope**: the fjord landscape alternates between hills and dips. The steepness of a slope affects the soil erosion potential as well as the water streaming: a sharp hill will suffer from regular soil renewal and nutrient depletion, while a flat area will store higher water and carbon  content [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007a; @zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013].
- the **aspect**: South- and East-facing slopes will receive more, and more intensive sunlight than West- and North-facing ones. The combined aspect and angle determine the heat load received by the slope [REF].
- the **soil compaction**: soil structure plays a major role in plant root development, and subsequent exchanges within the rhizosphere [REF], and arthropod movements and potential cover against disturbance [REF]. Soil compaction, assessed with the measure of bulk density, usually increases with grazing intensity [REF]. Thick grass root mats can also stiffen the soil [REF], thus an in-field penetration test can provide complementary information to the regular bulk density measurement.
- the **soil chemical composition**: nitrogen and phosphorus are the most studied plant limiting factors in agronomy [REF]. As high concentrations favor competitive fodder species, we can expect a correlation between nutrient load and dominant grass communities. Soil pH will affect the availability of nutrients by altering their chemical forms, and can therefore influence the plant species composition [@zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013].
- the **structural diversity**: available ecological niches for beetles are highly dependent of the heterogeneity of the aboveground biomass. It can be explained by feeding preferences (e.g. phytophagous) or strategies (e.g. hunters by sight) [REF]. Taller vegetation is usually associated with higher cover and more diverse niche potential [REF]. On the other hand, presence of very short vegetation patches or exposed ground will be important niches for some groups [REF].
- the **soil moisture**: beetles are very sensitive to moisture gradients [REF] and some families such as Hydrophilidae and Ptilidae will be mainly hygrophilous [REF]. The bryophyte layer will help to maintain the ground humidity during the summer season [REF].

## Reconciliation human and nature

- A lot of land sharing research is focused on the Southern hemisphere, less in the North (e.g. @ranganathanSustainingBiodiversityAncient2008; @steffan-dewenterTradeoffsIncomeBiodiversity2007)
- smallholders emphasize the positive effects of small-scale farming on local communities, economy & cultural landscape -> different perspectives between the full-time "historical" farmer (National farmer organisation) and the part-time who includes broader perspectives (National smallholder association) [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006]

## Perspectives in ecological research

- more focus on arthropods more relevant [@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997]
- a key asset of Nordhordland Biosphere Reserve agricultural landscape is its mosaic-like heterogeneity. Though we touched on the mosaic effect at the field-scale (ref Ã˜Y) and we considered landscape as a variable (ref fjord), we never actually analysed the landscape mosaic [@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997]. Landscape-scale studies would be complementary to field-scale studies and would allow an interesting approach on farm multifunctionality beyond ecological perspectives only.

## Transdisciplinary research

- @altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004 Traditional small-scale farming systems all around the world could serve as models for developing new sustainable pathways. Ecologists have a role here to dissect the processes and feedback between farmers and agroecosystems so they can be translated into practical guidelines and policies for sustainable food production and land management.
- @altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004 There is a complementarity between the long-term, empirical
- Farmer knowledge is specialist to the area, but "trans-disciplinary" in the practice. Ecologist knowledge is generalist, theory-based, more comprehensive in terms of underlying processes, but the approach is more narrow, discipline-based
- @foleyGlobalConsequencesLand2005 There is increasing need for both cross-disciplinary and trans-disciplinary research to develop and implement targeted policies for sustainable use of the land which would address short-term human needs, long-term preservation of ecosystem services and resilience of anthropogenic systems.
- @wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018 different visions of the farmer and the ecologists -> they can agree for a common management (e.g. APHM) but for different reasons -> failure of the scheme to bring farmers and scientists on the same perspectives. Also limited traditional ecological knowledge of farmers, which limits their participation/incentives in the making of a management plan, though such management plan can encourage the building of "endogenous knowledge" (**thus key to build endogenous knowledge**). Such schemes should engage actively farmers and be flexible (e.g. hay-cutting time) to encourage experimentation even if it looks like a "bad idea" from first glance
- Increase of complexity of land management arrangements between farmers [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010] which may challenge coordinate management measures according to common scheme.
- interdisciplinary research -> needs common reference frame (common definition & understanding of concepts) [@dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001]
